question_text.markdown:
Bond dissociation energy of E-H bond of the H$_2$E hydrides of group 16 elements follows order:

(A) O, (B) S, (C) Se, (D) Te

(JEE Main, 30 Jan 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) O > S > Se > Te**

Bond dissociation energy of E-H bond decreases down Group 16 as atomic size increases and bond length increases. O-H bond is shortest and strongest. Te-H bond is longest and weakest.

question_text.markdown:
**Assertion A:** The first ionization enthalpy of 3d series elements is more than that of group 2 metals.

**Reason R:** In 3d series of elements successive filling of d-orbitals takes place.

(JEE Main, 31 Jan 2023)

options.text: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
Both (A) and (R) are true but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) Both true and R explains A**

A is TRUE: 3d elements (Sc-Zn) have IE1 generally higher than Ca (Group 2) because d-electrons add nuclear charge without proportional shielding. R is TRUE: Successive d-orbital filling occurs in 3d series. R explains A because the d-electrons increase effective nuclear charge, raising IE.

question_text.markdown:
For electron gain enthalpies of the elements denoted as $\Delta_{eg}H$, the incorrect option is:

(JEE Main, 01 Feb 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) is incorrect statement**

EGE becomes less negative down a group (less exothermic). So Te should have more negative EGE than Po (Te is above Po). The correct order is EGE(Te) > EGE(Po) in magnitude, meaning delta_eg_H(Te) < delta_eg_H(Po) is actually CORRECT. Wait - let me reconsider: going down Group 16: S > Se > Te > Po in EGE magnitude. So Te has less negative EGE than Se but more negative than Po. Statement (4) says delta_eg_H(Te) < delta_eg_H(Po), meaning Te is more negative than Po. This is CORRECT. Actually option (1) is the incorrect one: Cl(-349) has MORE negative EGE than F(-328), so delta_eg_H(Cl) < delta_eg_H(F) is CORRECT (Cl is more negative). The answer key says option (2) is incorrect: Se(-195) and S(-200), so S has more negative EGE. delta_eg_H(Se) < delta_eg_H(S) means Se is more negative than S - this is WRONG since S is more negative. So option (2) is the incorrect statement.

question_text.markdown:
The first ionization enthalpies of Be, B, N and O follow the order:

(JEE Main, 25 Jul 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) B < Be < O < N**

IE1 (kJ/mol): B(800) < Be(899) < O(1314) < N(1402). Two anomalies: Be > B (Be has stable filled 2s2, B has one 2p electron easier to remove); N > O (N has half-filled 2p3 extra stability, O has paired 2p4 electron with repulsion).
